markdownRemark.html:
Score: 90

inquirer.net  (WEB - en-US)

The website of an English-language daily newspaper published in the Philippines.

This website generally maintains basic standards of credibility and transparency.
Does not repeatedly publish false content
Gathers and presents information responsibly
Regularly corrects or clarifies errors
Handles the difference between news and opinion responsibly
Avoids deceptive headlines
Website discloses ownership and financing
Clearly labels advertising
Reveals who's in charge, including any possible conflicts of interest
The site provides names of content creators, along with either contact or biographical information

Ownership and Financing

The paper and its website are owned by the Inquirer Group of Companies, a media group that owns other newspapers, magazines, and TV stations in the Philippines. In 2017, Filipino billionaire Ramon Ang acquired a majority stake. The website earns revenue through advertising and subscriptions.  

Content

Inquirer.net provides coverage of regional and international news, entertainment, technology, and business in the Philippines. News regularly features stories about prominent Filipino politicians and business figures such as Janet Lim-Napoles, the alleged mastermind of a scam that funneled government money into “ghost projects" that were implemented by Napoles's companies.

Inquirer.net covers business topics such as the Philippine Stock Exchange, the local job market, and real estate projects. The Entertainment section features stories about Filipino cinema, local arts, and theater. The Inquirer also covers sports and lifestyle features. The Associated Press provides coverage of international news.

Credibility

Staff reporters, columnists, and editors, create content for inquirer.net. Headlines are straightforward and reflect the information in stories.

The Inquirer has a record of covering corruption at local and national levels. The paper has been critical of Joseph Estrada, a one-time actor who is the former president of the country and the current mayor of Manila. He was elected president in 1998 but impeached amid corruption allegations in 2001.

In 2013, the Inquirer broke the story of the Priority Development Assistance Fund, or “ghost projects,” scam in a six-part series.

In May 2018, Inquirer.net removed three opinion stories related to a controversial rape case allegedly involving Philippine Senate President Vincente Sotto III, a known supporter of President Rodrigo Duterte. Sotto wrote to the Inquirer a few days after he was elected as Senate president, stating that the allegations “have been negatively affecting my reputation for the longest time.” The Inquirer published a statement that said it had removed the stories because the writer failed to provide substantive evidence of his claims against Sotto. The Inquirer’s owner, Ramon Ang, is also a supporter of President Duterte.

The Inquirer did not respond to NewsGuard’s two emails seeking comment about how these unsubstantiated stories made it to publication. The Inquirer does not provide a corrections policy, but NewsGuard found that it does regularly correct factual errors in its stories. It places them prominently at the top of stories.

Transparency

The Inquirer names the authors of its stories but does not provide information about them. The website also does not provide the names of its editors, senior staff, or ownership. Advertising is clearly labeled.

The Inquirer did not respond to NewsGuard’s two emails seeking comment about why it does not provide information about its writers and senior staff.

History

The Inquirer, which was founded in 1985, was one of the first private newspapers to be established under the presidential regime of the late Ferdinand Marcos.

Written by:
Evan Haddad

Edited by:
Amy Westfeldt Jim Warren
